facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 14, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 54 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 14, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 54 of 1957. N. Rajagopal Sastri and D. Gupta, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment of the Supreme Court delivered on February 14, 1962 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. Feburary 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J-The assessee, who is the respondent here, had received on July 20, 1946 a a sum of Rs. 40,000/-

facts.text: The assessee received a sum of Rs. 40,000/- on July 20, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J-The assessee, who is the respondent here, had received on July 20, 1946 a a sum of Rs. 40,000/-. In the proceedings for assessment for the assessment year, 1946-47, this came to the numberice of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: The receipt of Rs. 40,000/- came to the notice of the Income-tax Officer in the assessment proceedings for 1946-47.

anchor.surface_text: In the proceedings for assessment for the assessment year, 1946-47, this came to the numberice of the Income-tax Officer. Since the receipt fell within the accounting year relative to the assessment year, 1947-48, the Income-tax Officer did number assess the amount making a numbere, The question will however be companysidered again at the time of 1947-48 assessment.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer did not assess the Rs. 40,000/- in 1946-47 as it fell in accounting year for 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: Since the receipt fell within the accounting year relative to the assessment year, 1947-48, the Income-tax Officer did number assess the amount making a numbere, The question will however be companysidered again at the time of 1947-48 assessment. In the return filed for the assessment year, 1947-48, this amount was number shown by the assessee.

facts.text: The amount of Rs. 40,000/- was not shown by the assessee in the return for assessment year 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: In the return filed for the assessment year, 1947-48, this amount was number shown by the assessee. The Income-tax Officer also overlooked the numbere at the end of his order in the back years assessment, with the result that this item was omitted, The asseessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner against his assessment for the year, 1947-48.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer overlooked the note about the Rs. 40,000/- in 1946-47 assessment order, omitting it from 1947-48 assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer also overlooked the numbere at the end of his order in the back years assessment, with the result that this item was omitted, The asseessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner against his assessment for the year, 1947-48. While the appeal was pending, the Income-tax Officer wrote a letter to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner intimating him that he would like to be present, and also requesting him to assess the amount of Rs. 40.000/-

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner against assessment for 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: The asseessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner against his assessment for the year, 1947-48. While the appeal was pending, the Income-tax Officer wrote a letter to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner intimating him that he would like to be present, and also requesting him to assess the amount of Rs. 40.000/-

facts.text: Income-tax Officer wrote a letter to Appellate Assistant Commissioner requesting to assess Rs. 40,000/- while appeal pending.

anchor.surface_text: While the appeal was pending, the Income-tax Officer wrote a letter to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner intimating him that he would like to be present, and also requesting him to assess the amount of Rs. 40.000/-. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, after issuing numberice, assessed the amount and included it in the original assessment The companytention of the assessee was that the amount of Rs. 40,000/- represented a receipt of a capital nature, while it Was held to be a receipt on the. revenue account.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner issued notice and included Rs. 40,000/- in the assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, after issuing numberice, assessed the amount and included it in the original assessment The companytention of the assessee was that the amount of Rs. 40,000/- represented a receipt of a capital nature, while it Was held to be a receipt on the. revenue account. With this companytroversy, we are number companycerned.

facts.text: Assessee contended that Rs. 40,000/- was a capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the assessee was that the amount of Rs. 40,000/- represented a receipt of a capital nature, while it Was held to be a receipt on the. revenue account. With this companytroversy, we are number companycerned. The Tribunal agreed with the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, but on the application of the assesse, referred two questions to the High Court under s.  66  1 .

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal held Rs. 40,000/- as revenue receipt.

anchor.surface_text: while it Was held to be a receipt on the. revenue account. With this companytroversy, we are number companycerned. The Tribunal agreed with the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, but on the application of the assesse, referred two questions to the High Court under s.  66  1 . These questions were Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of- the cases the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was companypetent to enhance the assessment of the Appellant for the assessment year 1947-48 by a sum of Rs. 40,000/- ?

facts.text: Tribunal referred two questions to High Court under s.66(1) on assessee's application.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal agreed with the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, but on the application of the assesse, referred two questions to the High Court under s.  66  1 . These questions were Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of- the cases the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was companypetent to enhance the assessment of the Appellant for the assessment year 1947-48 by a sum of Rs. 40,000/- ? Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the said sum of Rs. 40,000/is a revenue receipt anti assessable to tax in the assessment year 1947-48 ?

facts.text: First question to High Court: Whether AAC competent to enhance assessment by Rs. 40,000/- for 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: These questions were Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of- the cases the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was companypetent to enhance the assessment of the Appellant for the assessment year 1947-48 by a sum of Rs. 40,000/- ? Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the said sum of Rs. 40,000/is a revenue receipt anti assessable to tax in the assessment year 1947-48 ? The High Court answered the first question against the Department, and declined to answer the second, in a much as it become academic.

facts.text: Second question to High Court: Whether Rs. 40,000/- is revenue receipt assessable in 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the said sum of Rs. 40,000/is a revenue receipt anti assessable to tax in the assessment year 1947-48 ? The High Court answered the first question against the Department, and declined to answer the second, in a much as it become academic. This appeal has been filed with special leave, against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay.

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered first question against the Department and declined second as academic.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question against the Department, and declined to answer the second, in a much as it become academic. This appeal has been filed with special leave, against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay. The question which arises in this appeal may be formulated thus whether in an appeal filed by assesee, the Appellate Assistance Commissioner can find a new source of income number companysidered by the Income-tax Officer and assess it under his powers granted by s. 31 of the Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal filed with special leave against Bombay High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been filed with special leave, against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay.

facts.text: It is admitted by the assessee that Appellate Assistant Commissioner can enhance assessment within sources considered by Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner can enhance the assessment. It is admitted- also by the assessee that within the four companyners of the sources processed by the Income-tax officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner can enhance the assessment. This power must, at least, fall within the words enhance the assessment, if they are number to be rendered wholly nugatory.

facts.text: High Court held that AAC powers confined to what was before Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held, following its earlier view in Narrondas Manordas v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1 , that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner has revisional powers, but that they are companyfined to what was before the Income-tax Officer and companysidered by the latter.

facts.text: In Jagarnath Therani case, Patna HC held AAC cannot assess new sources of income.

anchor.surface_text: The earliest case which companysidered the meaning of s. 31 3 , was Jagarnath Therani v. Commissioner of Income-tax   decided by the Patna High Court. In that case, the assessee had three businesses at Purnea, Jalpaiguri and Calcutta. His income from Purnea only was assessed by the Income-tax Officer. On appeal by the assessee the Appellate Assistant Commissioner assessed him with regard to the income from the other two businesses.

facts.text: Supreme Court did not express final opinion on AAC powers to include new sources in McMillan case.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax v. M s McMillan Co.  1  but the question, with which we are companycerned, was left open. There is, however, a passage in the judgment, approving of the observations of Chaola, C. J., in Narrondas Manordass v. Commissioner of Income-tax  2  to the following effect It is clear that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner has been companystituted a revising authority against the decisions of the Income- tax Officer

facts.text: Supreme Court approved that AAC has revisional jurisdiction to enhance assessment but question of new sources open.

anchor.surface_text: This Court, however, gave approval to the opinion of the learned Chief Justice of the Bombay High Court that s. 31 of the Income-tax Act companyfers number only appellate powers upon the Appellate Assistant Commissioner in so far as he is moved by an assessee but also a revisional jurisdiction to revise the assessment with power to enhance the assessment.

facts.text: No amendment to s.31(3) despite multiple Income-tax Act amendments in 37 years.

anchor.surface_text: The Income- tax Act was amended several times in the last 37 years, but numberamendment of s. 31 3  was undertaken to nullify the rulings, to which we have referred. In view of this, we do number think that we should interpret, s. 31 differently from what has been accepted in India as its true import, particularly as that view is also reasonably possible.

concepts.unlisted_description: Power of Tribunal to refer questions to High Court

anchor.surface_text: under his powers granted by s. 31 of the Income-tax Act ? Section 31 reads as follows 31.  1  The Appellate Assistant Commissioner shall fix a day and place for the bearing of the appeal, and may from time to time adjourn the hearing. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner may, before disposing of any appeal, make such further inquiry as he thinks fit or cause further inquiry to be made by the Income-tax Officer.  3 in disposing of an appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner may, in the case of an order of assessment,-  a  companyfirm, reduce, enhance or annul the assessment,  b  set aside the assessment and direct the Income-tax- Officer to make a fresh assessment after making such further inquiry as the Income-tax Officer thinks fit or the Appellate Assistant Commissioner may direct and the Income-tax Officer shall thereupon proceed to make such fresh assessment and determine where necessary the amount of tax payable on the basis of such fresh assessment There is numberdoubt that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner can enhance the assessment.

concepts.interpretation: Appellate Assistant Commissioner has revisional jurisdiction to confirm, reduce, enhance or annul assessment but cannot introduce and assess new sources of income not considered by Income-tax Officer; limited to sources processed by ITO and matters before him.

arguments.claim: Powers of AAC extend to matters considered by ITO; new source requires remand; assessing fresh sources deprives assessee of findings by two tribunals and one appeal

By the exercise of the power to assess fresh sources of income, the assessee is deprived of a finding by two tribunals and one right of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it must not be overlooked that there are other provisions like s. 34 and 33B which enable escaped income from new sources to be brought to tax after following a special procedure.

arguments.claim: Uniform judicial interpretation limiting AAC powers accepted by legislature; no amendment to s.31(3) in 37 years despite multiple amendments to Act

anchor.surface_text: In view of the provisions of ss. 34 and 33B... the view expressed uniformly about the limits of the powers... has been accepted by the legislature... The Income-tax Act was amended several times in the last 37 years, but no amendment of s. 31(3) was undertaken to nullify the rulings.

holdings.text: s. 31 of the Income-tax Act confers not only appellate powers upon the Appellate Assistant Commissioner in so far as he is moved by an assessee but also a revisional jurisdiction to revise the assessment with power to enhance the assessment.

anchor.surface_text: This Court, however, gave approval to the opinion of the learned Chief Justice of the Bombay High Court that s. 31 of the Income-tax Act confers not only appellate powers upon the Appellate Assistant Commissioner in so far as he is moved by an assessee but also a revisional jurisdiction to revise the assessment with power to enhance the assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court in McMillan approved Chagla CJ's view in Narrondas that AAC has revisional jurisdiction beyond mere appeal, including enhancement power.

holdings.text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner cannot enhance the assessment by travelling outside the record (assessee's return and ITO's assessment order) to find and assess new sources of income not disclosed or considered therein.

anchor.surface_text: The only question is whether in enhancing the assessment for any year he can travel outside the record, that is to say, the return made by the assessee and the assessment order passed by the Income-tax Officer with a view to finding out new sources of income, not disclosed in either.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Uniform High Court interpretation over 37 years (Jagarnath Therani, Gajalakshmi, Narrondas) limits powers to record before ITO; legislative acquiescence via no amendment to s.31(3) despite Act amendments; ss.34,33B provide for new/escaped sources.

holdings.text: s.31 should be interpreted in accordance with the uniform judicial view accepted in India limiting AAC enhancement powers, and not differently.

anchor.surface_text: The Income- tax Act was amended several times in the last 37 years, but no amendment of s. 31 3  was undertaken to nullify the rulings, to which we have referred. In view of this, we do not think that we should interpret, s. 31 differently from what has been accepted in India as its true import, particularly as that view is also reasonably possible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature accepted limits via non-amendment; alternative broad view possible but rejected in favour of settled narrow interpretation supported by special procedures in ss.34,33B.

holdings.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner can enhance assessment within the sources processed by the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner can enhance the assessment. It is admitted- also by the assessee that within the four corners of the sources processed by the Income-tax officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner can enhance the assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed and necessary to give meaning to 'enhance the assessment' words in s.31(3).

anchor.surface_text: In view of the provisions of ss. 34 and 33B by which escaped income can be brought to tax, there is reason to think that the view expressed uniformly about the limits of the powers of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner to enhance the assessment has been accepted by the legislature as the true exposition of the words of the section. If it were number, one would expect that the legislature would have amended s. 31 and specified the other intention in express words. The Income- tax Act was amended several times in the last 37 years, but numberamendment of s. 31 3  was undertaken to nullify the rulings, to which we have referred. In view of this, we do number think that we should interpret, s. 31 differently from what has been accepted in India as its true import, particularly as that view is also reasonably possible.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner can enhance the assessment. It is admitted- also by the assessee that within the four corners of the sources processed by the Income-tax officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner can enhance the assessment.

In view of the provisions of ss. 34 and 33B by which escaped income can be brought to tax, there is reason to think that the view expressed uniformly about the limits of the powers of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner to enhance the assessment has been accepted by the legislature as the true exposition of the words of the section. If it were number, one would expect that the legislature would have amended s. 31 and specified the other intention in express words. The Income- tax Act was amended several times in the last 37 years, but numberamendment of s. 31 3  was undertaken to nullify the rulings, to which we have referred. In view of this, we do number think that we should interpret, s. 31 differently from what has been accepted in India as its true import, particularly as that view is also reasonably possible.
